explanation:
Needed symbols and why:
- MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3: directly called by the target function. Any for-loops in its body (or their correctness) must be examined because the MISRA rule treats the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body semantics.
- MHD_get_rq_bauth_params_: called by MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3 (per the call graph). Its implementation may contain for-loops or modify objects used as loop counters/flags; include it to check for MISRA compliance recursively.
- MHD_base64_to_bin_n: called by MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3. Base64 decoding routines often contain loops; its loops must be inspected for well-formedness and for unexpected side-effects on objects visible to callers.
- MHD_DLOG: logging function invoked by both the target and its callees on error paths. Although unlikely, it may contain loops or side-effects that affect loop analysis; include it to be sure no for-loops or modifications relevant to the MISRA rule are hidden there.
- struct MHD_BasicAuthInfo: the target function reads fields (username_len, password_len, username, password) from this struct. Definitions are required to determine whether those fields are aliases, volatile, or otherwise shared/modified by functions called from for-loops in callees (affects the permissibility of using those objects in loop clauses).
- struct MHD_Connection: the target passes the connection to callees and to MHD_DLOG; its definition is required to see if any fields accessible to callees are modified inside loops (affects the rule about objects other than the loop counter being modified).

Note: I focused on the direct callee tree from the static call graph and the concrete data structures accessed by the target function. To be exhaustive, provide the full source of each listed function and the struct definitions; only then can all for-loops reachable from the target be checked against the MISRA for-loop constraints.
